Anansi and Turtle 
 Ghanaian folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Anansi the spider picked some
 
 yams from his garden. 
 
 They were extra beautiful delicious yams,
 
 so he baked them carefuly in the fire.
 
 
 Then he sat down to eat them up.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Just as Anansi was about to put the first 
 
 bite in his mouth, he heard a knock on 
 his dor. “Oh, no!” thought Anansi. “Who 
 
 can that be?” But he opened the dor. 
 
 There was Turtle, who loked very tired. 
 
 Turtle said, “Anansi, please let me in. I've 
 walked so far today, and I'm so tired and 
 
 hungry.” 
 
 So what could Anansi do but let him in? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi was to selfish to share his
 beautiful delicious yams with anybody
 
 else. So he came up with a nasty plan.
 
 
 Just as Turtle sat down at the table and
 began to reach for some yams, Anansi
 yeled at him, “Turtle, your hands are al
 
 dirty! You can't eat with your hands al
 dirty! Go wash them.” 
 
 
 Turtle's hands realy were dirty. So he
 slowly crawled to the river, washed his
 
 hands, and then crawled back. 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But meanwhile Anansi had started 
 gobling up the yams. By the time Turtle 
 
 got back, he saw that the yams were al 
 gone. 
 
 
 Turtle loked at Anansi. “Thank you for 
 inviting me to diner. If you're ever near 
 my house, please come by and let me 
 
 return the favour,” said Turtle. 
 
 
 And Turtle began crawling slowly away to 
 his house. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 As time went by, Anansi began to think
 
 more and more about how Turtle had
 promised to fed him a fre diner. So
 one day he walked over to Turtle's house.
 
 
 Anansi got to Turtle's house just about
 
 dinertime, as the sun was going down
 over the river. Turtle was lying on a rock
 in the sun, warming himself up, as turtles
 
 do. 
 
 
 When Turtle saw Anansi, he said, “Helo
 there, Anansi, have you come to have
 diner with me?” 
 
 And Anansi said, “Yes, that would be very
 nice, thank you.” He was geting hungrier
 and hungrier. 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Turtle dived down to the botom of 
 
 the river to set the table for diner and 
 get everything ready. Anansi waited on 
 the rocks by the shore. 
 
 
 Son Turtle swam back up and said, “Oh 
 Anansi, it is al ready now, please join me 
 
 for diner.” And Turtle dived down again 
 and began to eat the gren leaves he had 
 
 for diner. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi tried to dive down to the botom
 of the river, but he was a spider, not a
 
 turtle, and he couldn't dive that dep. He
 kept floating back up to the surface
 again. 
 
 
 He tried jumping in, he tried diving in, but
 
 nothing helped. He just couldn't get down
 to that diner. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Finaly Anansi had an idea. He put lots of 
 
 stones in the pockets of his coat, and 
 finaly he was heavy enough to sink down 
 to the botom of the river. 
 
 
 How clever he was! 
 
 
 He saw Turtle's table, ful of juicy gren 
 leaves and lots of other delicious fod. 
 
 Anansi's mouth was watering. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But just as Anansi was reaching for
 
 some of that delicious fod, Turtle
 stoped him. “Anansi, surely you're not
 going to eat diner with your coat on?
 
 That's not how we do things at my
 house.” 
 
 
 Anansi, without thinking, said, “Oh, of
 course you're right, Turtle, what was I
 
 thinking?” He tok of his coat.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But without the rocks in his pockets to 
 hold him down, Anansi floated right back 
 to the surface of the river again, and 
 
 poped out of the water. 
 
 Anansi sadly put his head down into the 
 
 water and watched Turtle eat up al of 
 the delicious fod! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10
